item.title: Cloud Hosting vs VPS
item.description: Virtual Private Servers (VPS) offer a hosting solution for websites that have outgrown shared hosting but aren’t ready for the cost and responsibility of a fully dedicated server. However, a new option allows for flexible scaling and a pay-as-you-go model: cloud server hosting. Discussions about cloud computing versus managing your own data center are becoming increasingly common. However, many companies haven’t reached the stage where investing in a complete in-house data center is necessary.

item.title: Infrastructure as a Service Providers
item.description: Cloud computing is widely understood to have three main levels: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), Platform as a Service (PaaS), and Software as a Service (SaaS). The most fundamental of these is IaaS, which forms the basis for the other two. IaaS essentially refers to providing basic hardware and operating system software over the internet. Infrastructure is fairly self-explanatory: it’s the foundational hardware and software needed for computing. When considering cloud infrastructure, the comparison is often made with having your own data center.

item.title: Hosted Cloud Computing
item.description: There’s a good reason for the growing interest in cloud computing. The uncertain economic climate makes the pay-as-you-go model increasingly appealing. This, combined with almost instant scalability, results in a computing environment where costs mirror business activity, minimizing the need for large upfront investments. Cloud computing offers additional advantages, particularly in disaster recovery and business phone systems. Consider the impact of natural disasters like hurricanes or earthquakes on traditional data centers.

item.title: Cisco's Unified Computing Cuts Costs and Power
item.description: Cisco’s Unified Computing technology aims to make data centers more efficient. Recognizing the enduring role of virtualization, Cisco fully embraces it to enhance performance and cut expenses, leading to reduced power usage. You might be reminded of Unified Communications (UC) when hearing about Unified Computing. UC aims to combine all forms of business communication, such as phones, emails, faxes, voicemails, and instant messaging, into a single infrastructure. A good example is Kall8’s feature that sends faxes and voicemails to your email.

item.description: Affordable, high-bandwidth Wide Area Networks have led to the rise of almost everything as a “service.” Mainframe computers were once centralized and isolated within corporate infrastructures, while PCs functioned as standalone devices with their own software and storage. However, virtualization is changing our understanding of where computing resources should be located. Software as a Service (SaaS) allows users to access familiar desktop tools like word processors, databases, and spreadsheets without the burden of purchasing, installing, and maintaining expensive software.

item.title: Can You Benefit From New Cloud Networks?
item.description: You’ve been reading about cloud computing and might be wondering if it can help your small or medium-sized business (SMB). While it seems like cloud services are designed for large corporations, they offer significant potential for businesses of all sizes. The cloud can be even more beneficial for SMBs because it levels the playing field. Large companies often have the resources to build their own private clouds, while smaller companies may struggle with the cost and staffing required for such an undertaking.

item.title: Private Cloud In a Kit
item.description: Cloud computing offers significant advantages, but you might be hesitant to move your sensitive applications to a public cloud environment. Fortunately, there are alternatives to public clouds. Besides public clouds, there are also private clouds and hybrid clouds. Hybrid clouds combine public and private cloud environments, allowing you to run less sensitive applications on the public cloud while maintaining more sensitive data on a private cloud. While public cloud cost savings are well-known, you might wonder if private clouds offer similar benefits.

item.title: How Does Cloud Computing Work In Business?
item.description: The term “cloud” is frequently used today. But what exactly is it, and how can it benefit your business by improving efficiency, speed, and affordability? Let’s delve into it. In business, the term “cloudy” often carries a negative connotation, implying uncertainty and unpredictability. Naturally, clarity and predictability are preferred, especially from a financial standpoint. Therefore, it’s understandable why people might be skeptical when advised to transition their business to the cloud.

item.title: Cloud Computing For Disaster Recovery
item.description: This year has seen a lot of natural disasters, from massive fires and overflowing rivers to intense storms and widespread tornadoes. These events might make you worry about your business’s safety. It’s true that unexpected events can impact anyone. item.title: How The Cloud Provides Virtualization For The SMB
item.description: Virtualization has been a popular topic for large businesses for a while. It allows them to maximize their existing resources, turning one server into multiple virtual ones and distributing heavy workloads across platforms. But can smaller businesses also benefit from virtualization? The answer is a resounding yes, thanks to the cloud. The cloud’s power lies in virtualization, enabling it to function as a massive data center accessible to numerous users. By efficiently utilizing virtualization, cloud providers can create an illusion of infinite resources, making each user feel like the sole user.
